comments.text:
+Alex Zarandi The Church, aside from being a completely Western 
institution, has the same amount of influence in some Western European 
countries (Spain, Italy, etc) as it has on Latin American countries (Chile, 
Argentina, etc).

I don't know about London, as I have never been there, and Prague is 
Eastern European, so whether it belongs to the West is debatable. But you 
are wrong about Paris. Many Latin American cities, while being built, where 
in many ways modeled after European ones because of the enormous European 
influence among the ruling elite, and French influence was huge among them 
during the XIX century. Also, Rio and Manaus are terrible examples, and, 
because of geographical and climatic reasons, not very representative of 
Latin American cities at all. Latin America isn't reduced to tropical 
climates, it is extremely diverse. Think Santiago, Montevideo or Lima, and 
compare them to cities like Madrid, Lisboa, Paris and many more. There are 
also cities, such as Blumenau in Brazil or Frutillar in Chile that look 
extremely German, apart from other countless examples. But, still, this is 
a terrible argument: if I was standing in the middle of Prague I could 
never imagine myself to be in New York, as you implied, because both cities 
are extremely different. Cuzco, for example, would be more appropriate, 
because of all the buildings the Spanish built, in the same Baroque style 
that is so prevalent in Prague.

Also, no, they aren't very different culturally, and that is even without 
globalization mixing everything up. They are predominantly European, just 
as much as the USA or Canada are, and have been that way since the Spanish 
(and Portuguese) conquered the continent and imposed their culture. Yes, 
native elements are stronger in Latin America, because the Spanish, in 
general, didn't choose to murder the natives in the way the English and the 
Americans after them did, but these native influences aren't very 
prevalent, especially in comparison to the European heritage and influence 
in Latin American culture and society. The heritage from Ancient Green and 
Rome, the Renaissance, the Enlightenment, the influence of the Catholic 
Church, the massive use of romance languages... Latin America is, 
definitely, Western.

comments.text:
I'm comparing Europeans to Africans and Native Americans, not East Asians. 
 In the Americas there was only one really successful staple crop and that 
was corn.  The Aztecs successfully cultivated it, but if a virus struck the 
crop there was a famine.  Europe (and Asia) had a diversity of staple crops 
to choose from.  Pure luck.  Africa does not have as many natural ports as 
Europe, despite it's size.  The Americas have many natural ports, but their 
strongest beast of burden was the lama.  Lamas are just not as strong or as 
fast as horses.  Thus, Native Americans could not move goods and ideas over 
great distances like Europeans could.  Beasts in Africa are very resistant 
to domestication.  Once again, luck.   The black death, as devastating as 
it was,  gave the surviving Europeans a stronger immune system than the 
Native Americans.  Thus, Native Americans were wiped out by diseases that 
Europeans would just shrug off.  Again, pure luck and nothing more.

The fact that Europeans lagged behind others until recently only proves my 
point.  If they were innately superior, they would have been ahead the 
entire time.  Instead, they were merely lucky for a number of centuries.

comments.text:
Fukuyama is right about attributing the importance of legal accountability 
to the success of a state, but he is wrong about contributing it to 
Christianity. The Christian legal system was unique to Western Europe in 
that it promotes the divine rule of kings and thus the divine authority of 
kings over their subjects. The Germanic (Folkright Law, Witenagemot, 
Icelandic þing etc.)  and Celtic legal system (Brehon etc) placed all 
people of a state, including the ruler, under the same legal rules and 
regulations. The average person could take the king to court and had land 
rights. This formed the basis of the English kingship and made many of 
these systems distinct from other systems of kingly authority. These 
systems were eventually replaced with the Christian system. Elizabeth I's 
replacement of traditional law with Christian law is often cited as a 
contributing factor of the dispossession of the poor and the rise of the 
British working class in later years.
comments.author: shirehorse91

comments.text:
Other theories on the rise of early Western technology is that it is 
protected by mountains on one side and the formidable North Atlantic on the 
other. Only Western Atlantic cultures had the technology to handle the 
formidable North Atlantic and thus developed the technology to control the 
world's trading routes. For example, Britain's global empire was about 
control of the oceans and not an actual military invasion.

comments.text:
+Jonathan Newcombe "But why does the east have the values you have ascribed 
to it?"

Because philosophers like Confucius, Han Feizi, and others developed these 
philosophies in China and subsequent Chinese dynasties adopted them and 
spread these values across Asia.


"What events shaped these beliefs"

The warring states period in China for some reason was a major time for 
philosophers to come forward and put forth their philosophies. It also 
coincides with the axial age which was sort of a intellectual renaissance 
for the Greeks, Chinese, Indians, etc. 

"Where in practice did countries in the Orient put them into practice?"
China had the rule of law since before the Roman Empire came into being and 
the rule of law has shaped its society since (rulers were never seen as 
gods or above the law I can give an example if you are interested).

China also gave up imperialism in the 15th century due to Confucian values 
(they still practiced some imperialism but Western countries have acted 
against their values at times as well i.e. slavery)

"Where can we see examples of these same values working in a positive way 
for the people in these countries today?"

Rule of law exists in many if not most countries in Asia. Even corrupt 
countries have a rule of law. A country like North Korea does not have rule 
of law because they believe that their ruler is above the law but a country 
like South Korea does have a rule of law and a strong one. A corrupt or an 
authoritarian country like China has the rule of law because their leaders 
are subject to it. Rule of Law is a stepping stone to democracy but doesn't 
necessarily entail democracy.

+Mattheaus The Apostate I have no knowledge of US high school AP 
curriculum, but that was where I was introduced to a People's History, 
along side the AP Review/Prep Book. While we did practice for the AP test, 
learning AP's style and strategies just for it (instead of showing our 
knowledge), I recall thinking, 'This isn't history! What is Zinn talking 
about?' I tried to chop it down the best a High Schooler could for where I 
came from, and whom I was surrounded by- to ask about historiography may 
have been a good senior course to compliment the AP class. You want to push 
the student but if you overload him or her, you may cause them to buckle 
and the information will fly right by. My AP class almost did that so I 
wonder if incorporating a focus of viewpoints of history is possible. Or 
maybe it should be implemented earlier on as not to take history at face 
value and how to critique... I'm rambling now. Apologies.

Side note, when I said "rewriting history" I was thinking of "Revisionist 
History", which is such a funny name to me, as I think of now as a time of 
tech and "science" where revision is always open-ended. Should the act of 
collecting history not always be revised as new facts come to light? If so, 
has there been recent changes to the classic histories we've encountered? I 
have little knowledge of historiography from this point so It may be too 
meta or some other fancy word...
comments.author: Evan B

+Evan B That's a fair point. He does offer a viewpoint of US history that

My major issue with Zinn's work other than that too many seem to take it as 
factual simply because it offers a different narrative, is that it's being 
taught in a lot of schools as the truth(which he pushed for).

I doubt any caveats are being thrown towards the children learning it about

Zinn's work should be presented just as you described it. It's representing

Zinn's presentation of history is likely not 100 percent accurate nor all

comments.text:
+Beorn Borg The idea that american history is simply the story of an elite 
vs the masses is his thesis. He frames his entire revision around this. 

If you want an example, simply look at his explanation of the american 
revolution, or at the other end of the time line at his explanation  the 
9/11 terrorist attacks and subsequent war on terror.

In the former he simply says the sole motive behind the american revolution 
was some nefarious plot by the colonial elite to distract everyone from 
their problems. I can not accept such a simplistic explanation for the 
revolution, because history is rarely that simple, and any explanation that 
claims otherwise should be taken with a grain of salt.

The founders did not and never had one mind about how the country should be 
structured and this is shown by how much debate took place before & after 
the revolution, especially leading up to the ratification of the 
constitution following the failure of the articles of confederation.

The idea that the main motive was the distract the masses via war with a 
superpower is just silly to me. 

In the latter he completely ignores religious influences on the motives of 
the terrorists(al qaeda's ideology and goals, that of global caliphate and 
the spread of Sharia law, is explicitly religious in nature), and 
essentially says it is due solely because of western influence in Saudi 
Arabia(which would only offend because of the presence of Mecca and Medina) 
or sanctions against the secular regime of Saddam(which doesn't really make 
sense, Saddam wasn't really a friend of Al Qaeda) and the on going Israeli/ 
Palestine conflict, or at least the US support for Israel(which itself an 
incredibly complex issue which he assumes one side on) are the reasons that 
Islamic terrorism exists. 

It ignores the fact that many other regions and peoples that suffered even 
more under imperialism have not formed global terrorist organizations, and 
the fact that western values(like freedom of religion and liberation of 
females) are the most cited problem that organizations like Al Qaeda, or 
Boko Harram or [insert jihadist group here] have with the west.

Plus it also fails to explain why western peoples are willing to be 
radicalized(as shown the recent ISIS issue). Why those born and raised in 
western prosperity are willing to flock and die for some theocratic army.

His best moments are when he covers both the Vietnam war and the occupation 
of the Philippines by the US(the latter deserves more coverage), but his 
attempts to explain the entire history of the US as that of simple class 
conflict just doesn't work as the blanket answer he seems to want it to be.

top_comment.text:
Not to mention, John Green doesn't mention WHY the West rose, only that it 
did... somehow. I'll explain what Green failed to:

1. Starting in the Middle Ages (about the year 1000), Western Europe began 
to stabilize, forming increasingly ordered societies. Although Viking 
attacks were still a problem in the north, they were really just a nuisance 
to most societies at this point. The Magyars and Muslims had been defeated 
at Lechfeld and Ostia, and Christian missionaries had converted the Poles 
and would soon convert the Scandinavians. Much of this order and relative 
political stability was accomplished through use of castles, knights, and 
the feudal system. This wouldn't last as long as some people thought, but 
it had its purpose.

2. Once order was restored, long-distance trade was safer. With the rise of 
a single super-national cultural regime (Catholicism), norms between 
nations were established, and trade between and within said nations rose 
greatly. This rise in trade led to the growth of towns, and with them, a 
rise in the money economy. This, in turn, gave more power to monarchs who 
could more easily tap into trade-based taxes than nobles who derived most 
of their income from feudal dues from farmers on their estates.

3. Although it served to help stabilize Europe, the feudal system would 
ironically be undone by the very stability it helped to create. With the 
rise of money economies, nobles became slowly but increasingly defunct as a 
class. The new wealth increasingly belonged to a new class of merchants and 
bankers as the Middle Ages came to an end and the Renaissance began.

4. Several contributing factors gave this positive change a huge push 
forward. First was the black death. While devastating, it led to a labor 
shortage which had the effect of increasing the wages paid to the laborers. 
Catholic Europe's social system gave enough power to the workers that they 
were able to take advantage of their situation, and were empowered enough 
to inherit wealth from their relatives who died from the plague. This was 
not the case in most places outside of Europe, where similar (or more!) 
deaths from the bubonic plague did not lead to a windfall for the peasantry.

5. Another factor was the rise of gunpowder weapons which helped make 
knights and castles obsolete, thus weakening the nobles who depended on the 
strength of their castles and loyalty of their knights. The expense of 
maintaining a gunpowder-equipped army meant that only kings and the very 
richest of nobles could afford one. It helped that unlike China, Europe 
actually had real guns. The Chinese invention of gunpowder is no more 
similar to guns than gasoline is to inventing a car. A hand cannon 
(impractical and hard to aim) is not the same as a gun (super useful, easy 
to aim, deadly if it hits, despite a long reloading time), after all.

6. But perhaps the largest long-term factor in the rise of the West was the 
establishment of the University system. Much as the rise of philosophy and 
academies fueled the rise of the Classical world, so did the Western, 
Catholic, European, Italian invention of the University. Before you say 
anything, no, Classical, Byzantine and Islamic schools don't count as 
universities. A university is a specific kind of degree-granting 
institution which teaches a wide variety of subjects and possesses academic 
and intellectual indpendence. Only an institution with ALL of these factors 
is a university, and the very first one started in Bologna in the year 1088 
AD. And that's AD, not CE.

7. With a larger economy, freer intellectual climate, and with increasingly 
centralized states, the West had caught up with the rest of the world 
absolutely no later than the 1200s AD, and pulled ahead in the next century 
or so. While it is true that a few individual states (like the Mongol 
protection racket that was called an empire) were larger than any one 
Western state, the West as a whole was still richer and more powerful than 
any other culture.

8. This would be made clear for all to see in 1492, when the Moors were 
beaten and Columbus went off to the Americas. A few decades later, the 
largest empire in the world was Spain's, the first time a Western state had 
been the largest by land area in 1000 years or more. Other empires followed 
suit, such as Portugal, the Netherlands, France, and of course, Britain. 
Russia, while Western in my book, took a different course, building a 
large, Orthodox, land-based state which conquered Central and Northern 
Asia, leaving the rest to Western Europe.

9. A few major turning points (in no order of importance or dates) are:

- *Battle of Lepanto*: The Ottomans lost to a massive Christian fleet, 
coming not too long after an earlier defeat at Malta. While the Ottomans 
held onto Cyprus and rebuilt their fleet, their navy had too few sailor and 
not enough money, so it was left to rot anyway. The West gained permanent 
and decisive naval superiority over Islam, plagued by pirates on occasion, 
but never threatened in any serious way.

- *Battle of Diu*: There was more than one of these, but the effect was 
that Portugal gained control of the Indian Ocean trade. This trade would 
pass to Dutch and British control later on. The point is, Islam and the 
Indians lost control of this trade and never got it back.

- *Conquest of the Aztecs and Incas*: Cortes and Pizarro conquered the only 
major empires which existed in the Americas at the time, ensuring the 
colonization of those areas and a massive shift of silver and gold to Spain 
and Europe. While this had some negative consequences (such as inflation!), 
the conquest left a permanent mark on the world.

- *The Scientific Revolution*: While the West had been ahead of the East in 
science and technology for some time by the 1600s, the scientific 
revolution put the West so far ahead as to make any comparison a joke. So 
many discoveries, inventions, and innovations were made, it is hard to 
describe. Here are a few:
    
     - Heliocentrism and the telescope
     - Theory of Gravity
     - Laws of Motion
     - Calculus
     - Latitude and Longitude
     - The Modern Steam Engine
     - The Railroad
     - The Bessemer Process and modern steelmaking
     - Germ theory and the microscope
     - Laws of Conservation and Thermodynamics
     - The Scientific Method itself

Some big names which the East could never match were: Newton, Galileo, 
Kepler, Copernicus, Gauss, Leibniz, Priestly, Boyle, Jenner, Benjamin 
Franklin, Cassini, and Lavoisier. And all of them lived before figures such 
as Edison, Einstein, Planck, Hubble, Lemaitre, and dozens of others. I 
didn't even mention Darwin or superior Western understanding of biology, 
apart from germ theory.

10. The development of capitalism. Business practices had changed little in 
the East, where customary rules dating back many centuries still ran 
things. This is why China, a vast country, had a smaller economy than tiny 
Britain. By rationalizing their economies, the West was able to channel 
money towards to best business practices, eliminate wasteful and 
inefficient firms, promote innovation, and encourage entrepreneurship. And 
while all this was happening, the East was still mostly stuck with serfs 
and private merchants. While a handful of Eastern figures were rich, the 
West was clearly ahead.

The main reason the gap between the West and the rest has closed somewhat 
is due to Easterners adopting *Western ways*. Just look at Japan. That 
capitalist economy and open political system is *not* native to their 
culture.﻿
top_comment.author: Nonamearisto

Well, I have a far stronger explanation, and I have more details which make 
it stronger still.

Europe had developed the idea of personal salvation and therefore, personal 
responsibility to and for God. The idea of individual rights and 
responsibilities was therefore more highly developed in European 
jurisprudence and philosophy than anywhere else, where people were treated 
primarily by their class or caste.

Although the distinction between commoners and nobles still existed in 
Europe, it was far more porous than elsewhere: kings often sold titles of 
nobility to rich merchants and bankers, and serfs could often *buy their 
own freedom* from their lords... when they didn't just run away to a town!

As for lack of development elsewhere, that is a bit more complex. It 
depends on the place. I suppose if there is any major, common element 
between these underdeveloped areas, it is the lack of intellectual freedom 
relative to Europe. This also helps to explain the lack of a scientific 
revolution outside of the West.

with wars that spanned the european continent, so I really would not give 
too much credit to european political institutions.

Imho, ultimately what made the west powerful is precisely the cultural urge 
to measure things with numbers that you criticized in your video. It 
allowed the scientific revolution to happen, but it also had less obvious 
consequences such as providing demand for very accurate watches and 
measuring apparatus. The body of skilled watchmakers also used their 
experience to build very sophisticated automata, which evolved into the 
machinery that made the industrial revolution possible.

It really becomes apparent when you look up biographies of the great 
inventors during the first industrial revolution. Almost all of them had a 
background as scientific instrument makers/watchmakers, even though these 
were a tiny portion of the population. But the interest of the elite in 
measuring things allowed some people to make their living making 
sophisticated machines, which ended up being a big deal.﻿

top_comment.text:
I was wondering... Since this was about history and stuff, could you make a 
video about the things we need to know for AP history tests? I'm taking AP 
US History (APUSH) and I'm not really sure what I will need to absolutely 
know for the test, and what I need to know but not quite memorize. My 
teacher is new this year and won't really give me an answer and only two 
kids from my school passed the test last year. I don't wanna be one of the 
ones to fail, and I'm pretty sure there are others out there that feel the 
same. ﻿
top_comment.author: Leah B

comments.text:
+Leah B  ... Leah, it's been years since I've taken my AP tests (it was 
1996, actually, so you're talking to an old broad), so I can't give you 
specific answers about what was on the test, but I can offer at least some 
general guidance and advice based on my personal experiences from the tests 
... sorry in advance for the text wall

1) don't panic... to quote Doctor Spock "You know more than you think you 
do" ... you've been studying this shit all term. you have to have picked up 
something

2) be well-rounded... the test won't focus on any one 
era/location/paradigm. it's going to be asking about all kinds of things, 
so general knowledge will be more helpful than, say, a specific knowledge 
of every date of every battle in the War of 1812

3) supplemental instruction never hurts ... if there's any specific think 
in the books that you aren't sure of, or that just interests you in 
general, there are online forums crammed with amateur (and professional) 
historians who will happily go on at length ... also, each of your 
textbooks should have an appendix in every chapter mentioning which books 
and articles they used to get their information. these can be very 
informative and very interesting as well, so check them out and see if any 
titles catch your eye (learning can be a source of pleasure, too. if you 
haven't already gotten savvy to that, please do. you're never too old to 
discover new things or to enjoy that)

4) your teachers are a resource, too ... don't feel weird about cornering 
them and asking these questions, or demanding clarification on points that 
weren't 100% clear

5) there are hint books available at most major book stores ... and they 
are hella expensive, so i'd recommend sitting down with the book and a cup 
of tea inside the book store and taking notes there, lol ... but there are 
books that will tell you what current and/or recent tests have been 
focusing on

6) don't panic ... I know i already listed this, but it's important. lots 
of people get test anxiety, almost zero actually benefit from it. learn to 
meditate if you have to, just don't walk into that test-room freaking out. 
it's called state-dependent memory. if you weren't freaking out when you 
learned the info, it'll be a lot easier to recall if you aren't freaking 
out when you test on it

... whew, okay, sorry again for the text wall, but it was a lot to cover 
... to put it in context, i took 4 AP tests and got between 3 and 5 on all 
of them (granted, i worked my arse off in the classes themselves and

Hey Leah B,
I got a 5 on my AP US History Exam last year so I can give you some good 
direction. Here is my personal advice:

Know that the AP curriculum has changed. The nineteenth century is no 
longer as focused on as it used to be so you won't have to worry about it.

Instead of reading straight from the book you have, I would recommend 
buying the American Pageant book and studying that. That in itself is a 
bunch more work but, to put it into perspective, when I took US History as 
a Junior I got a 2 (I didn't use American Pageant). As a senior I bought 
the American Pageant book and solely relied on it; I wound up with a 5.

Hope this helps!

top_comment.text:
I was super excited to watch this video but Crash Course has done a pretty 
bad job with this one. You have provided a variety of perspectives but you 
have missed an obvious and vital part of the "equation" (considering we're 
using numbers to quantify history now): the West only became a hegemonic 
power in the last three or four centuries. This video talks about the West 
as though it was destined to be hegemonic from the beginning - an archaic 
and ignorant understanding that many modern historians would dismiss in a 
heartbeat. Every assessment presented here takes that same stance, as 
though history is some kind of linear narrative. All of the examples in 
this video have a subtle prejudiced undertone, suggesting that the West is 
"the best" because it has something that second and third world countries 
don't have. Weber's idea of Western hegemony being caused by the protestant 
values of hard work and rational thinking seem to have made a comeback. 
Most of these attitudes are a hangover of colonialism. Most importantly, 
Crash Course is reinforcing these ideas to a largely teenage demographic - 
don't we have enough Eurocentric world views already? I'm super 
disappointed in whoever wrote the script for this video. I would be happy 
to send you some articles and book titles that will help to expand your 
worldview.﻿

From a Chinese perspective, the success of the West is driven mainly due to 
colonialism, slavery, and proximity of coal from industrial centers. In 
short, exploitation of land, people, and resources. Before the industrial 
revolution, China and India had roughly the same GDP per capita as the 
west, China surpassed the west in standard of living up until the 
1600-1700's. However, China did not practice colonization, chattel slavery 
(a specific form of slavery only the West practiced), and their cities were 
far from coal mines. Thus, they were not able to kick-start their own 
industrial revolution.
Source: "When China Rules the World" by Martin Jacques

When the West criticizes China on their "exploitation of land, people, and 
resources", they should realize that no industrialized country in the world 
achieved industrialization with as much protection of property rights, 
human rights, and environmental protection as China.﻿

comments.text:
+MrSnertje
Meh. I agree that the harnessing of energy (in a very broad sense of the 
term) is a defining feature in the success of human societies, but this is 
hardly a surprising or innovative conclusion. Historians have always been 
aware of this. The real question is: how do some societies become more 
successful at harnessing energy than others? Diamond's book has at best a 
mixed record when answering these questions.

"You wrongly differentiate pastoral nomads from agrarians: herding is still 
agriculture"
Then your problem is with Diamond, who defines agrarian societies as 
settled farming communities, and places pastoralists in a separate 
category. How we're defining the term "agrarian," however, is really beside 
the point. What matters is that Diamond claims that settled farming 
communities are better at harnessing energy than pastoralist ones, and thus 
tend to be more successful, yet he fails to account for the many examples 
in history where pastoralists have conquered farmers.

"exploitation of such a vast swathe of land as the Americas (not comparable 
in size or wealth to Manchuria or Mongolia)"
So what? It's not at all clear that the size of the territory controlled 
correlates with the economic or agricultural success of the country that 
controls it. Spain was still the largest Western empire during the 
eighteenth century, yet Britain, which at that time controlled a relatively 
small amount of land and people, was by far wealthier and more innovative. 
Increases in an empire's land area do tend to bring economic advantages, 
but not axiomatically-- like, every time an empire adds a square kilometer, 
it doesn't automatically become wealthier and more powerful. Thus you still 
haven't explained why conquering Mongolia, Manchuria, and Tibet wouldn't 
have given China the same advantage as, say, conquering the Eastern 
Seaboard gave to Britain.

Moreover, as historians like BD Wong, Kenneth Pomeranz, and Jonathan K. 
Thornton have demonstrated, the same kinds of economic and technological 
revolutions that Europe experienced during the 16th and 17th centuries were 
also happening in China, the Middle East, India, and parts of sub-Saharan 
Africa. Europe doesn't appear to have diverged from the rest in terms of 
the pace of economic growth and innovation until the late eighteenth 
century. If conquering the Americas allowed Europe to develop at a faster 
pace than Asia or Africa, why did it take two hundred years for this effect 
to kick in?

"give him a break and revel in his genius"
Absolutely not! That would encourage bad scholarship. I'll give Diamond 
credit for what he does right, but I insist on criticizing him for what he 
does wrong; otherwise, future scholars would have no incentive to try to 
improve on it.
comments.author: Alice Gull

comments.text:
+Alice Gull While some of your criticism is warranted, and Diamond in the 
end doesn't convincingly explain the rise of the West, his thesis is an 
essential link in a broader theory of the Rise of the West.
In essence it is all about energy. Through agriculture mankind harnessed 
more of the sun's energy than ever before, allowing us to develop new 
technologies, which in turn made the harnessing of energy more productive. 
You can easily see that this is a positive feedback loop.
Agrarian societies therefor take an immediate lead over non-agrarians. (You 
wrongly differentiate pastoral nomads from agrarians: herding is still 
agriculture.) 
Diamond in my eyes irrefutably argues why Eurasian agrarians became 
dominant over others (and most importantly Americans).
Europe being the one to be able to use this advantage to actually conquer 
the Americas basically explains its advantage over the rest of Eurasia. The 
exploitation of such a vast swathe of land as the Americas (not comparable 
in size or wealth to Manchuria or Mongolia!) greatly improved the West's 
energy production: through new crops European populations grew, furthermore 
colonization allowed excess population a place to go, which of course 
continuously increased production. Besides, as was explained in a recent CC 
World History video a larger base of people generates more innovators: 
another positive feedback loop. A combination of positive feedback loops 
meant that while ca. 1500 Europe was at best the equal of the rest of the 
Old World and at worst a backwater, it grew to dominate even the mighty 
states of the Orient by the 19th century. 
As said, for all its problems Diamonds theory is essential in understanding 
the Rise of the West, precisely because it as you said so commendably 
explains the conquest of the Americas. In the end he is not a historian, 
but a biologist, a fact from which most of your issues stem, but his work 
is nevertheless of great historiographical importance so give him a break 
and revel in his genius!
comments.author: MrSnertje

comments.text:
+TheTokkin
I take your point about nomadic warriors and technology. I'd still argue, 
though, that pastoral nomads are a problem for Diamond's argument, because 
so much of his book concerns the development of agriculture. According to 
him, the civilizations that develop agriculture earliest are able to 
produce more food, which allows them to devote more time and labor to 
developing technology, amassing military force, and creating more complex 
social structures. This doesn't square well with the success of 
non-agricultural nomadic peoples.

Once again, it doesn't matter whether China *needed* to develop 
economically productive institutions and innovations; the fact is that it 
*did* develop them. As historians like Wong and Pomeranz have documented, 
China and Europe underwent a similar economic transformation during the 
Early Modern Period, characterized by the expansion of commerce, a rising 
standard of living, and an increasing pace of technological development. In 
some ways, China's institutions were closer to the ideal than Europe, as 
there were no guilds and fewer state monopolies to restrain economic 
activity. It is true China's transformation never grew into an industrial 
revolution, but this likely had more to do with the abundance of coal in 
Europe than with institutional differences.

"India is no big mystery. It was largely governed by powerful Muslim 
kingdoms"
So what about non-Muslim powers in contemporary India, such as the Maratha 
Empire and the Sikh Empire?
comments.author: Alice Gull

comments.text:
Yes, the nomads were more developed in terms of technology -- where it 
mattered. They developed archery and bow-making that farming peoples 
couldn't emulate. It was these traditions and technologies that made any 
nomadic warrior a much more powerful opponent than a sedentary soldier with 
a musket. But musket armed soldiery were deployed in much larger numbers. 
The Ottoman empire, Manchu Empire, Mughal Empire all relied on technologies 
and skills developed by nomadic warriors.

My point is, I suppose, that its wrong to argue that the Eurasian nomads 
constituted a  *seperate* inferior civilization to that of their sedentary 
neighbors. That isn't really true. The nomads were just people with a 
different lifestyle.

Of course the Chinese had developed various institutions, but because the 
monarchy was so powerful, they had no need to embrace innovations and 
institutions that could create potential power rivals like economically 
autonomous corporations.

India is no big mystery. It was largely governed by powerful Muslim 
kingdoms that governed by sharia law, which never embraced innovations like 
corporations. Not that sharia had no alternative: they promoted the use of 
Waqfs, or Islamic charitable foundations that provided virtually all 
municipal services and so forth. They had one major problem though: they 
were not economically autonomous but entirely restricted by their 
foundational documents. So if a waqf wanted to invest in a new technology 
or provide a new service, they had to apply for permission from a judge. 
They also developed no book-keeping or sharing holding, etc, obviously.

Waqfs were ubiquitous in Muslim governed and influenced parts of the world, 
and they were very inflexible. Restricted institutions like this were also 
very appealing to rulers, because they couldn't invest in dissenting 
political causes.

The emerging industrial technologies were very capital intensive. You could 
import a steam engine from England, but if all your private companies were 
tiny fragmented partnerships between camel merchants, that was unlikely to 
happen. Industrialization required quite developed economic institutions.

Bad institutions also lead to huge corruption, which is still a pervasive 
problem in these parts of the world. If every economic change needed 
approval from authorities, bribery became the normal way to make things 
move forward.
comments.author: TheTokkin

comments.text:
+TheTokkin
"pastoral nomads were extremely innovative in areas of warfare and because 
of their harsh livestyle, they often proved much better fighters than 
farming people"
Innovative in terms of battle tactics and strategies, yes, but not in terms 
of technology. There's little question among historians that, say, the 
Mongols were less technologically advanced than the Abbasids or the 
Chinese, yet the Mongols still conquered both civilizations. This is a 
problem for Diamond, whose thesis about food production relies on the 
assumption that greater technology leads to greater martial success.

I'm not disputing that Europeans developed more profitable institutions and 
practices than the Chinese, Ottomans, and so forth. I'm disputing Diamond's 
claim that competition, driven by Europe's balkanized geography, was the 
primary reason for this development. It's not at all clear that societies 
that face competition tend to be more technologically or economically 
innovative than those that do-- if that were the case, India, a highly 
fragmented and competitive subcontinent for most of its history, should 
have become just as advanced as Europe during the eighteenth century.

"the Ming didn't need to develop policies to enhance economic institutions"
But the point is that regardless of whether they had to develop such 
policies (and I would argue that they did just as much as Europe, 
regardless of their geography), they *did* develop them. As historians like 
Wong and Pomeranz have demonstrated, China remained a highly innovative and 
dynamic society in economic, technological, cultural, and military terms 
throughout the Ming and Qing dynasties. Commerce grew, specialization 
increased, and the standard of living rose. It's not clear that Europe 
surpassed China in any meaningful sense until the eighteenth century.

Now, it is true that European innovations ended up producing more wealth 
than Chinese ones-- but it's not clear that this was because Europeans were 
more innovative. Pomeranz documents that China continued to innovate at 
about the same rate as Europe through the eighteenth century (c.f.- 
Pomeranz, "The Great Divergence," 47). The Rise of the West probably had 
more to do with the presence of abundant coal deposits in Europe than with 
any difference in the quality or quantity of European innovations.
comments.author: Alice Gull

comments.text:
+Alice Gull 

>"Missing from this discussion is any serious treatment of 
technologically-backward pastoral societies that conquered their more 
advanced agricultural neighbors. The examples are numerous: the Turkic 
conquest of the Middle East, the Manchu conquest of China, the Celtic 
conquests in Europe, and the Mongol conquest of most of Asia, to name just 
a few. It seems that good tactics and equestrian skill can often more than 
outweigh the advantages of agriculture. What Diamond sees as an iron law of 
history turns out to be a pattern that sometimes occurs and sometimes does 
not, depending on other factors."

This is kind of nonsensical. The pastoral nomads were not technologically 
backwards. They lived on the harsh periphery of human civilization, but 
they constantly traded and interacted with agricultural empires adjacent to 
the steppes. The pastoral nomads were extremely innovative in areas of 
warfare and because of their harsh livestyle, they often proved much better 
fighters than farming people. Most empires in the Middle east and China 
were either established by nomadic conquerors or made extensive use of 
nomadic mercenaries. It wasn't until the emergence of capital intensive new 
technologies like sophisticated guns and eventually barbed wire, among 
others, that nomads conclusively fell behind in military terms.

The same emergence of capital intensive technology proved to be the 
downfall of Indian, Ottoman and Chinese empires. European societies were 
much better prepared to adopt these technologies on a consistent and large 
scale due to institutional developments that were initially difficult for 
most monarchies to endorse (without the rivalry of other polities). In this 
regard, Diamond is correct. 

Monarchies that predominated without competition, like the Ottomans and the 
Ming, didn't need to develop policies to enhance economic institutions. 
Usually, they did the opposite and weakened local institutions in favor of 
centralized power. 

The weaker European monarchies had to be more conciliatory and innovative. 
The English, Nordics, Swiss etc, for example, enforced the harsh 
inheritance policy of primogeniture which prevented the fragmentation of 
property and capital, which prevented uncertainty, preserved 
companies,which preserved skills and productive capital (i.e. tools). In 
contrast, in the Middle East and in India, where Muslim law mainly 
predominated, inheritance was much more egalitarian. If a successful 
merchant built up a large enterprise, he would have to bequeath it to 
numerous heirs (families were usually large in the middle ages, especially 
for rich men due to polygamy and concubinage) instead of appointing a 
single primogenitor as was the custom in parts of Europe. The successors 
could choose to continue the profitable business, but this usually proved 
impossible as everyone wanted a piece of the pie and productive capital was 
stripped, workers fired and properties sold. 

Europe's advantage in capital grew with the widespread adoption of joint 
stock companies that could draw upon the resources of thousands of 
shareholders. These companies could utterly crush local competition in the 
Ottoman empire and India.
comments.author: TheTokkin

comments.text:
Wall of text alert!

Guns, Germs, and Steel should have been a fifty-page essay about how the 
Spanish conquered the Aztecs and the Incas. His discussion of that topic is 
interesting, well argued, and reasonably well researched, particularly when 
he talks about why Europeans carried deadlier diseases than Native 
Americans. Diamond wasn't necessarily the first person to make such an 
argument, of course, but he probably made it more comprehensively than any 
of his predecessors. For this effort he deserves respect and commendation.

The problems start to crop up when Diamond begins to apply his thesis of 
environmental determinism to the rest of the world. Diamond believes that 
the same geographical influences that explain the European conquest of 
America also explain "the fate of human societies" generally. By all 
accounts they do not, but that doesn't stop Diamond from attempting extreme 
feats of mental contortionist to prove that they do. The following are some 
of the more egregious fallacies that appear in Diamond's work.

1. Shameless cherry-picking
The central thesis of Guns, Germs, and Steel is that civilizations living 
in regions that are geographically suited for agriculture tend to become 
dominant. Earlier development of agriculture, combined with the ability to 
cultivate more and better crops and domesticate more and larger animals, 
gives a civilization a surplus of food, leaving many of its inhabitants 
free to develop better technologies. Domestication of animals also exposes 
a people to a wider range of diseases, building immunities. By virtue of 
their superior technologies and higher levels of immunities, these 
civilizations are able to conquer their less-advanced pastoralist and 
hunter-gatherer neighbors.

Diamond cites a number of examples from human history to prove his theory. 
The European conquest of America is a prime example. Thanks to Eurasia's 
abundant domesticable animals, Europeans carried and were immune to a wide 
range of diseases which nearly exterminated the Native Americans. Europeans 
also had more advanced technology than Native Americans, thanks in part to 
the wider range of crops available in Eurasia. Similarly, the Bantu were 
able to conquer most of Africa, and the Maori the Moriori, because of early 
leads in food production.

Missing from this discussion is any serious treatment of 
technologically-backward pastoral societies that conquered their more 
advanced agricultural neighbors. The examples are numerous: the Turkic 
conquest of the Middle East, the Manchu conquest of China, the Celtic 
conquests in Europe, and the Mongol conquest of most of Asia, to name just 
a few. It seems that good tactics and equestrian skill can often more than 
outweigh the advantages of agriculture. What Diamond sees as an iron law of 
history turns out to be a pattern that sometimes occurs and sometimes does 
not, depending on other factors.

None of this is to say that Diamond's findings on these subjects aren't 
valuable. There's no question that agriculture, and technology in general, 
plays an important role in conflict between societies, and Diamond is 
probably right to link it to the Bantu expansion, the conquest of the 
Americas, and other such events. It is not, however, a universal law of 
history, and Diamond's presenting it as such is irresponsible and 
dishonest. Had he truly taken all the evidence into account, he would have 
identified these trends as "things that sometimes play a decisive role in 
history." But that would hardly have been as sonorous, or as provocative, 
as "The Fate of Human Societies!"

2. Acceptance of questionable historical claims
There are a number of instances in this book when Diamond attempts to 
explain historical trends that may not have actually happened. Essentially, 
Diamond takes a questionable or even discredited historical theory, accepts 
it as true, and then explains how environmental factors were ultimately 
responsible. This represents a lazy and self-serving approach to 
historiography; Diamond would rather parrot theories that confirm his 
thesis than actually try to get to the bottom of the events he's studying.

Take Diamond's treatment of Africa. He accepts without question that the 
civilizations of sub-Saharan Africa have always been less wealthy and less 
technologically advanced than those of Eurasia. This is a popular belief 
among lay Westerners, and it has some support in scholarly circles, but 
many historians have argued against it. John K. Thornton, for example, 
argues that Africa's underdevelopment is a relatively recent phenomenon in 
human history; before the eighteenth century, sub-Saharan Africa had many 
economic and technological developments over Europe (c.f.- Thornton, Africa 
and Africans in the Making of the Atlantic World). Even scholars who 
generally accept that Africa was always underdeveloped make exceptions for 
certain parts of Africa and time periods. Acemoglu and Robinson, for 
example, argue that civilizations of the Sahel region were "as developed as 
their contemporaries anywhere in the world" during the medieval period, 
even if Africa as a whole was relatively poor and backward (c.f.-- Acemoglu 
and Robinson, Why is Africa Poor?). Suffice to say that Diamond's theory 
doesn't work if the thing it explains didn't actually happen! Diamond, 
however, is either unaware of or unconcerned with the debate over Africa's 
development. This demonstrates either laziness or ignorance.

Another questionable claim that Diamond accepts is the idea that European 
colonization of the Americas gave Europe a definitive economic advantage 
over the rest of the world, leading eventually to the Industrial Revolution 
and the Great Divergence. As with the claim about Africa, this idea has 
some support in scholarly circles, but it is by no means universally 
accepted. Many historians argue that Europe gained no advantage from the 
Americas that, say, China did not gain from Manchuria and Mongolia, and 
thus that colonization cannot by itself explain the Great Divergence. 
Again, Diamond is either unaware of or unconcerned with the debate on this 
topic. He simply accepts it as true and proceeds to build a 
environmentalist argument around it.

Diamond's claims about Africa and colonization may be questionable, but at 
least they might be true; the same cannot be said about his argument about 
China. Diamond accepts a popular but now discredited myth about the Middle 
Kingdom: that during the Early Modern period, it became reactionary, 
inward-looking, and stagnant. This is demonstrably untrue. China continued 
to develop economically, technologically, culturally, and militarily 
throughout the period Diamond covers (c.f.- Pomeranz, The Great Divergence: 
China, Europe, and the making of the Modern World Economy). It was on the 
losing side of the Great Divergence not because it stopped developing, but 
rather because Europe began developing much faster. Diamond could have 
disabused himself of this myth by reading peer-reviewed historical research 
on the subject, or even just by comparing a map of China in 1600 to one of 
China in 1800, but he didn't do this. His scholarship is appallingly lazy.

3. Asserting convenient but unsubstantiated theories
Diamond is not entirely unaware of the weaknesses in his theory. At several 
points, he attempts to pre-empt his detractors by anticipating their 
objections and showing how they still fit his theory. These defenses 
generally come across as desperate attempts to stuff as many events as 
possible into his thesis. They are marked by his characteristic laziness 
and dishonesty, and ultimately fare no better under scrutiny than his other 
arguments.

Take Diamond's treatment of the Middle East. If Diamond is right that 
civilizations with early advantages in food production tend to become 
dominant, the Middle East presents a problem: it was the first region in 
the world to develop agriculture, yet it is by no means militarily, 
economically, or culturally dominant in the modern world. To explain this 
apparent contradiction, Diamond points to an ecological disaster that 
occurred in the region around the time of Alexander the Great's conquests. 
The area's fragile ecology, combined with poor water use and over farming, 
rendered Middle Eastern civilizations poor and backwards. This explains 
Alexander the Great's conquest of the Achaemenid Persian Empire, as well as 
all subsequent European advances over the region.

This would be convenient for Diamond if not for one problem: the Middle 
East didn't stop being dominant at that time. For nearly two thousand years 
after Alexander's conquests, the region remained a world leader in terms of 
economic, technological, and cultural developments. The Parthian and 
Sassanid Empires, the Umayyad and Abbasid Caliphates, and the Ottoman 
Empire were all at least as advanced as European civilizations at their 
heights; it isn't clear that Europe definitively surpassed the Middle East 
until the eighteenth century. Unless Diamond can explain how an ecological 
catastrophe took two thousand years to affect the region, this defense is 
merely a pathetic attempt to bandage a hemorrhaging thesis.

Another such bandage is placed on India, which provides a powerful 
counter-example to one of Diamond's arguments about China. As previously 
mentioned, Diamond parrots the discredited claim that China became a 
stagnant society and offers the following environmental explanation: 
China's geography predisposed it to political unification. Unification 
meant no competition, which meant China had no incentive to continue 
developing as a civilization. Even if we exclude the fact that China did 
not stagnate, it's not clear that political unification was the problem. 
India, after all, was politically fragmented for most of its history, yet 
it was no more successful than China after the eighteenth century.

To address this counter-example, Diamond suggests that just as too little 
fragmentation is a problem, so is too much. Indian states were so 
fragmented and so small, he asserts, that they were unable to develop 
effectively. There is, then, an ideal level of political fragmentation, 
which Europe possessed. China and India represent the two harmful extremes.

Diamond, of course, does not give detailed explanations of how political 
fragmentation affected India, let alone develop a theory for how we can 
assess the effects of fragmentation based on its degree. But there's a more 
basic problem with this argument: it's not clear that India was more 
fragmented than Europe during the period he's describing. Before the 
British conquest, the dominant power in India was the Maratha Confederacy, 
a state that was roughly five times the size of contemporary France. Even 
smaller Indian states, such as Mysore, still compared favorably in size 
with smaller European states like the Dutch Republic. It's not at all 
clear, then, that India's states were too small or too fragmented to 
function; they appear to have been quite similar to European states in this 
respect. Once again, Diamond proves that he's more interested in bolstering 
his thesis than in gathering and assessing facts.
comments.author: Alice Gull

I'm not sure on the rest, the lack of draft animals is a strong argument,

fever rampant, killing many MANY settlers in Virginia, Panama, etc. Both 
1493 and Guns, Germs and Steel borrow a lot from Alfred Crosby and expand 
upon it, which is a good thing I think. I think Jared Diamond has some very 
compelling points, I just think it lacks in a few areas. That being said, 
it's still an amazing book.
For an interesting examination of how indian and european empires

very bad odds.

That book also spends a large chunk of the first quarter of it explaining

survive at.   Cows, pigs, sheep, goats, wheat, barley, peas, etc were

trade routes to Europe, where the plants would grow in similar latitude 
ranges.   

No other places in the world had as many domesticated species as the 
Fertile Crescent.  Because of that advantage, less work was needed on 
getting food to eat. Thus, economics takes over and people specialized.

"standard" Native American diet was corn beans and squashes, supplemented 
by game hunting. The three grown together is actually pretty sustainable 
and nutritious.

+ALBO22 The Invasion of the Americas not only affected Spain and Portugal, 
but whole of Europe. The increase in wealth experienced by Spain coincided 
with a major inflationary cycle both within Spain and Europe, known as 
price revolution. Spain had amassed large quantities of gold and silver 
from the New World.

The increase in prices as a result of currency circulation fueled the 
growth of the commercial middle class in Europe, the bourgeoisie, which 
came to influence the politics and culture of many countries.

In the Age of Exploration navigators discovered new routes to the Americas 
and Asia. Commerce expanded, together with innovations such as joint stock 
companies and various financial institutions.

A variety of theories posit Europe's unique relationship with the New World 
as a major cause of the Great Divergence. The high profits earned from the 
colonies and the slave trade constituted 7 percent a year, a relatively 
high rate of return considering the high rate of depreciation on 
pre-industrial capital stocks, which limited the amount of savings and 
capital accumulation.

Early European colonization was sustained by profits through selling New 
World goods to Asia, especially silver to China. According to Pomeranz, the 
most important advantage for Europe was the vast amount of fertile, 
uncultivated land in the Americas which could be used to grow large 
quantities of farm products required to sustain European economic growth 
and allowed labor and land to be freed up in Europe for industrialization.

New World exports of wood, cotton, and wool are estimated to have saved 
England the need for 23 to 25 million acres (100,000 square km) of 
cultivated land (by comparison, the total amount of cultivated land in

top_comment.text:
Wall-O-Text alert!

For what it's worth, here's the theory I'm currently enamoured of (which I 
got from Tory MEP and journalist Daniel Hannan).  Be warned: it's something 
of a narrative, and is thus simplified (which the truth, as we all know, 
resists).  The success of "the West", and I'm going to treat that as a 
purely economic success because economic dominance is the source of 
military dominance which in turn is the usual source of political 
dominance, is as a result of what we commonly call "Western values" but 
which it would be more historically accurate to call "Anglosphere values".  
I'm not making some kind of claim to ethnic exceptionalism here; one of the 
great things about these values is their universal applicability and the 
ease with which they can be exported.  But the core values of freedom under 
the law, constitutional government and equality before the law, which along 
with secure property rights are the foundation of modern Western capitalism 
and the resulting wealth, can all be traced back, through both the US and 
English Bills of Rights, through the English Civil War, through even beyond 
Magna Carta, to the Anglo-Saxon folkright of the common law; a law that is 
the property of the people, a law that binds the head of state as surely as 
the meanest peasant (and something which, Francis Fukuyama notwithstanding, 
cannot be found in classical antiquity, nor in the hierarchical, 
Zoroastrian power structures of Catholicism).  Moreover, these values, and 
the things they imply (like regular elections, a free press, or indeed the 
equality of the sexes), though successfully exported to many parts of the 
world through history's least bad empire™, are by no means something which 
every nation discovers for itself as soon as it becomes wealthy and modern 
enough.  Indeed, their very survival was gravely threatened by the three 
great conflicts of the 20th Century - the two World Wars and the Cold War.  
Consider the world from the perspective of, say, 1941; almost the whole of 
the Eurasian landmass was under one form or another of totalitarianism, 
systems that elevated the state over the individual, emphasised sacrifice 
to the collective, martial glory and so on.  To the leaders of those 
systems it seemed that the liberal Anglo-Saxon model was on the way out; 
they called it "decadent Anglo-Saxon capitalism" or "rotten English 
liberalism", and they felt it surely could not stand against their 
nationalistic fascisms and collective communisms, where everyone was 
working towards a single great Purpose.  But they were defeated, by a 
combination of factors that all go back to the effects of the common law.  
It is through the common law that the Englishman, the American or the 
Australian is stubborn, bloody-minded - thus a determined soldier.  He is 
inventive, and will venture a new idea despite the disinterest of 
officialdom, because free markets have taught him to avoid groupthink - 
thus producing such innovative weapons as centimetric radar or the Mosquito 
bomber.  The economic productivity of the Anglosphere nation is greater 
for, though less work is extracted from its people than from the enslaved 
inhabitants of a totalitarianism, that work is better directed by the 
market system (see also Hayek & the Calculation Problem).  But perhaps most 
important of all, the blood-and-soil nationalism of the Continental 
European autocracy is contrasted with the civic nationalism of the 
Anglosphere.  Americans will often tell you with pride that theirs is a 
propositional nation - but that conception of nationhood was not invented 
ex nihilo in the Old Courthouse in Philadelphia; it was inherent in the 
nature of the Anglosphere, which anyone could join by signing up to a set 
of values and principles.  It was this binding idea of freedom under law 
that led so many Canadians, Australians, New Zealanders, Indians to travel 
up to halfway around the world to take up arms for a country that, until 
then, most had never even set eyes.  The entire Commonwealth joined in 
Britain's fight because it was their fight too; the fight between systems 
that elevate the individual over the State and systems that do the 
reverse.  And when the war was won, we taught, not only the Germans, but 
the whole of Western Europe, how to emulate and replicate our system of 
freedom and liberty, and it was only *then* that the values of the 
community of free English-speaking democracies became Western values.

tl;dr: the West is really the Anglosphere and the cause of its rise boils 
down to Magna Carta, symbol of freedom under law.﻿

comments.text:
+Arakash Europe's strength in (your example) the 16th century was that it 
was a plurality of small and competing nation-states, which forced each to 
be freer than the great empires of Asia.  Unlike those empires, Europe was 
never centralised; no one prelate or prince could arrogate the whole 
surplus production of a vast polity to satisfy the vanities of his court; 
by avoiding remote and arbitrary government, efficiency and freedom were 
promoted.  It is Europe's tragedy that just as Asia has discovered the 
benefits of market capitalism and dispersed powers, the EU has taken us in 
the opposite direction, towards the creation of a single European state.  
Fortunately, we seem to be on course to prevent that :)

Spain and Portugal strangled themselves by the mercantilist system.  Their 
skill at navigation, grown through a geographical situation that encouraged 
sea trade, gave them a great advantage in colonising the New World.  But so 
preoccupied were they with obtaining precious metals - mistaking, as they 
did, money for wealth - that their entire colonial enterprise was directed 
towards the importation of those metals, and the taxation of that 
importation to provide a revenue to the sovereign, the intention being to 
prevent re-exportation of those metals.  The full story can be found in 
Book IV of Adam Smith's Wealth of Nations, which chiefly consists of a 
criticism of the mercantilist system.

Why the Anglosphere?  Simply because, until comparatively recently, it was 
only in the Anglosphere that the law was held to be above the government, 
and it is only there that the law is the property of the people, grown case 
by case like a coral rather than written down in the abstract and then 
applied to specific cases.  It was this primacy of law that produced the 
secure property rights required for market capitalism and the Industrial 
Revolution.  You can see prefigurings of this in Adam Smith; wherever he 
compares commercial regulation between the UK and Europe, while the 
restrictions at home are denounced as illiberal and counterproductive they 
are always observed to be far more liberal in character than those on the 
Continent; and this can only be attributed to the way in which the 
government is seen as the servant of the people rather than their master.

Another factor is geographical; England's great rise to prosperity came 
after its Act of Union with Scotland, and most of the other Anglosphere 
nations have been islands (Australia; New Zealand; to an extent, North 
America considered as a unit).  An island nation has no need for a large 
standing army in peacetime, and thus the government (at least prior to the 
mechanisation of war that began around the turn of the 20th century) has no 
means of repression and control of its people.  Perhaps that is part of the 
reason why, while so much of Europe remained under rigid autocratic 
systems, the Anglosphere maintained its stubborn and ornery individualism.  
Moreover, Americans and Australians were both further from Europe's wars 
and inclined to produce a more liberal and individualistic society even 
than England; the same differences that European travellers in England 
observed as compared to their own peoples, were observed by English 
travellers in both those regions.  As de Tocqueville puts it: "The American 
is the Englishman left to himself."

I already covered, in the gp, a list of non-economic, Anglosphere reasons 
for Western military success.

If you want the full detail on this argument, by the way, it can be found 
in Hannan's book, "Inventing Freedom: How the English-Speaking Peoples Made 
the Modern World".  Alternatively, there are several talks he has given on 
the book that can be found on YouTube.
comments.author: Edward Cree

comments.text:
+xenoblad We can be objective within a well-defined framework. When we 
establish clearly what our values are, then we can judge objectively. I say 
it doesn't eliminate matters of taste because no matter how much I prove 
that such work of art is good or bad (even within a context that we share), 
you can still like it "for no good reason", so to speak, and you'd be 
totally entitled to like it that way.
And when I say any such analysis doesn't comprehend the work of art (or, 
better put, doesn't exhaust it), it's because we can always propose new 
points of view to analyse it. No single analysis will say all there is to 
say about a piece.

The whole "history is written by the winners" cliche is A: not always 
true, B: way too simplistic and C: implies that the history written by said 
victors is somehow illegitimate. You should really never discount a work on 
history just because it comes from a biased perspective. All history is 
biased and has a particular angle it's pushing, that's what this episode 
was all about. It is rare that historians outright lie in their writing, 
and even rarer that said lies become accepted for long periods of time.
